message: Today, I was proud to hit the ground running on the first day of the 115th Congress with the introduction of 15 measures addressing an array of important issues affecting our nation and world.

This Friday, I will be reintroducing my resolution condemning the Dog Meat Festival in Yulin, China, and urging China to end the dog meat trade. As you all know, during the Yulin Dog Meat Festival, 10,000 stray dogs and stolen pets are captured, caged, and slaughtered. This extreme spectacle of animal cruelty is both inhumane and a threat to public health in #Yulin.   We are currently in the stage of trying to get as many bipartisan original co-sponsors before we reintroduce the resolution this week. In the last Congress, all of your tireless efforts were the reason we were able gain the support of 161 bipartisan co-sponsors. Please join me in garnering support for this important resolution by calling your Congressman and asking them to sign on as an original cosponsor. I am proud to introduce my resolution regarding Haiti today, which urges the Secretary of Homeland Security to extend Temporary Protected Status to Haitian nationals residing in the United States. It is time that Congress lets the people of Haiti know that we recognize and care about the many hardships they face as they work diligently to establish a strong and vibrant democracy.

I voted in favor of H.Res.11, objecting to United Nations Security Council Resolution (UNSCR) 2334, a one-sided resolution that has pushed the Israeli-Palestinian peace process further out of reach.   While it is easy to be dismayed at the lack of progress in resolving this conflict, a permanent solution can only be reached through direct and bilateral negotiations between the Israelis and the Palestinians. Unfortunately, when the United Nations and its bodies support biased resolutions like this one, it only encourages the Palestinians to further avoid dialogue.   UNSCR 2334 is highly problematic. It fails to recognize Israel as a Jewish democratic state, while assigning all blame for the conflict on the Israeli government despite Israel’s repeated offers for peace. Even more troubling, the resolution defines all of East Jerusalem as a settlement, making no distinction between Jerusalem and remote outposts as settlement areas. This shows just how little the United Nations understands about the conflict. At the end of the day, UNSCR 2334 does nothing to improve the lives of the Palestinian people.    The Security Council does not have the right to adjudicate Israel, the only thriving democratic nation in a region engulfed in turmoil. This resolution should have never been brought up for a vote, and the United States should have used its veto authority rather than abstaining.   In the previous Congress, I introduced a resolution urging President Obama and Secretary Kerry to use the United States’ veto power on anti-Israel measures. I am proud to have co-sponsored this resolution, which objects to UNSCR 2334 and urges serious, direct negotiations between the parties.

In case you missed it, there were a few newsworthy developments from the Republican Congress yesterday.  First, in the rush to repeal the Affordable Care Act, Republicans announced that their budget will explode the deficit to more than $1 trillion by the end of the decade. After years of reductions by the Obama administration, this reversal would increase the national debt to $29.1 trillion by 2026. Some Republicans are describing the increases in spending as technicalities, but such a tremendous increase in our nation’s debt will be anything but a technicality to millions of hardworking Americans.   Secondly, in addition to working to drastically increase our national debt, Republicans have wasted no time and announced their plan to completely defund Planned Parenthood as they began their assault on women’s rights and health. Planned Parenthood has spent decades increasing women’s access to much needed health care services and must be supported and protected.  Finally, three Republican senators introduced legislation that would cut security funds for U.S. embassies around the world in half. In fiscal years 2018 and 2019, it would cut off all security, construction, and maintenance funding worldwide, except to pay for moving the Israeli embassy to Jerusalem. Such an action will put every U.S. embassy around the world at risk, proving once and for all that Republicans’ interest in the Benghazi attack was nothing but a political stunt.   Now that the Republicans control the government, they are showing their true colors. And it’s only more proof that all of their rhetoric is just lip service to the American people.

There are reports of an active shooter situation at Hollywood Fort Lauderdale International Airport. Information is still coming in.   My thoughts and prayers are with the victims, as is my gratitude for the first responders and security personnel working to keep us safe each and every day.

I am shocked and horrified at today’s shooting at Fort Lauderdale International Airport. Details are still coming in, but it appears that this cowardly act of violence has claimed multiple lives and left many people injured. My thoughts and prayers go out to the victims, and I offer my full support to the authorities on scene investigating this shooting.   As a frequent patron of this airport, this shooting truly hits close to home. I commend the Broward County Sheriff's office, TSA, and all emergency personnel who responded to this shooting and work tirelessly to keep us all safe day and night.

I have reintroduced my resolution condemning the #Yulin Dog Meat Festival and urging China to end the dog meat trade. The resolution will be numbered H.Res.30 for the 115th Congress.  I am deeply appreciative to the thousands of supporters who worked tirelessly to champion this resolution in the past year, and sincerely hope that Speaker Paul Ryan brings this measure to the floor for passage during the 115th Congress. This resolution is the first of its kind to focus Congress’ attention toward animal welfare issues overseas, and I will continue to do all that I can to end this barbaric and inhumane practice. I just introduced the Justice for Yazidis Act, legislation that will expand mental health, physical therapy, and other health services to religious minority groups that have suffered the greatest persecution under the Islamic State, including those subjected to rape, forced marriage, and sexual slavery.These programs, though modest, will help victims of genocide begin the long process of healing.

Once again a cowardly and barbarous act of terrorism has been carried out in Israel, this time against young Israeli soldiers and cadets on an educational trip overlooking the Peace Forest.   It is without question that the relentless demonization of Israel at the United Nations gives fuel to these attacks, as does the refusal of Palestinian leaders to condemn terrorism. Rather, as has happened so many times in the past, Palestinians in Gaza handed out sweets to celebrate the murder of four innocent Israeli youth.  I call on Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas to take this moment to unequivocally condemn this terror attack.  My thoughts and prayers are with the victims of this terrible act of violence. The American people share in the outrage of this heinous act and remain committed to the security of #Israel and the Israeli people.

As the Senate begins the confirmation process for the President-elect’s cabinet nominees, I am alarmed that many of the candidates have not yet been fully vetted by the nonpartisan Office of Government Ethics. This is unfortunately in keeping with the trend already established by the President-elect, who continues to refuse to disclose his tax returns or address other conflicts of interest.   Many of the nominees clearly have conflicts of interest, and a number of them have not yet completed their financial disclosures or ethics reviews. Until now, this has only happened once in the past 40 years, and is not something to be taken lightly. These nominees owe the American people transparency. Anything otherwise shows total contempt for our democratic process.    Additionally, I am alarmed by a number of the nominees announced in recent weeks. Rep. Tom Price, nominated to serve as Secretary of Health and Human Services, has said he wants to end the Medicare guarantee, while Dr. Ben Carson, nominated to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, previously declined a cabinet appointment citing his lack of experience running a federal agency. Just today, it was announced that Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., a vocal vaccine skeptic, was asked to chair a commission to investigate vaccine safety, having previously described effects of vaccines as the cause of a ‘holocaust.’   It is my sincere hope that moving forward we see a more transparent, comprehensive, and open process. Anything less is a disservice to the American people.

Today, I joined Congresswoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Congressman Ted Deutch, State Rep. Rick Stark, and Broward County Commissioner Nan Rich, alongside healthcare providers, working families, seniors, union leaders, and area youth in the fight to protect the Affordable Care Act.  Speaker Paul Ryan and President-elect Donald J. Trump have promised a quick repeal of the #ACA. According to the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, if the ACA is repealed, 24 million more people would become uninsured by 2021. This report also found that 14.5 million fewer people would have Medicaid coverage by 2021, 8.8 million fewer people would have marketplace or other non-group insurance, and 700,000 fewer people would have insurance through their jobs.  In Congress, I have worked to improve healthcare for all. And while it is undeniable that the ACA can be improved, tearing it up in its entirety will accomplish nothing. Health insurance is a life-or-death issue, not a partisan talking point.  If the GOP plans to repeal the ACA, they better sure have an actual plan that will protect the American people.  Anything less would be a complete disaster.  #ACAWorks

As we pause today to honor the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., our nation still faces many challenges.  Within days, we will inaugurate a President who has traveled the country making bigoted, offensive, and divisive comments.  We cannot continue moving forward together if our leaders seek to divide us.  We stand to lose years of progress, and the fight for equality has reemerged with just as much relevance today as it had during the Civil Rights movement. I, for one, will continue to push back against prejudice and discrimination, and oppose the demonization of any American regardless of the color of their skin.   As Dr. King once wrote, 'Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.' Let us not turn a blind eye to our fellow Americans in need, and look beyond our differences to truly lift our nation up as a whole.  I am forever indebted to Dr. King, who inspired and challenged us as he led the charge for equality, fairness, and justice for all Americans. Now more than ever, we cannot forget this lesson. #MLK

I have decided to boycott the Inauguration of President-elect Donald Trump and remain in my Congressional district in Florida. This decision is not a protest of the results of the Electoral College, but rather, an objection to the demagoguery that continues to define the incoming administration.   President-elect Trump has done little to prove that he is ready to lead this country. Instead, he continues to champion divisiveness. The office of the President is not endowed with unquestioned loyalty, and it is the obligation of each and every American to speak out against injustices however big or small. I cannot play a part in normalizing the countless offensive comments that he has made throughout the past year.  It is quite simply wrong for the President-elect to use his position of power to continue to make racist, sexist, and bigoted statements, to demean those who have spent their lifetimes championing civil rights, such as Rep. John Lewis, and to ridicule religious minorities, ethnic minorities, and anyone who looks different. President-elect Trump continues to denigrate the American intelligence community, jeopardizing the security of the American people, and has clear, undeniable conflicts of interest in violation of Article 1, Section 9 of the Constitution, designed to prevent foreign influence over American elected officials. Make no mistake: these behaviors are not, nor can they ever be, considered normal.   President-elect Trump has made it clear that when given the choice, he stands with Vladimir Putin. I choose to stand with Rep. John Lewis, and every American that expects our President to serve with compassion and humility. If the Trump administration continues to champion illegal, unconstitutional, or other ideas that put the safety of the American people at risk, it will find no harsher critic than me.

As President-elect Trump vows “insurance for everybody,” the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office has released a report examining the impacts of repealing the #ACA under the Republican alternative. The projections are frightening.   Under the GOP plan, “the number of people who are uninsured would increase by 18 million in the first new plan year following enactment of the bill... that number would increase to 27 million, and then to 32 million in 2026.”  Additionally, “Premiums in the nongroup market (for individual policies purchased through the marketplaces or directly from insurers) would increase by 20 percent to 25 percent—relative to projections under current law—in the first new plan year following enactment. The increase would reach about 50 percent in the year following the elimination of the Medicaid expansion and the marketplace subsidies, and premiums would about double by 2026.”  In Congress, I have worked to improve healthcare for all. And while it is undeniable that the ACA can be improved, tearing it up in its entirety would be completely disastrous. If the GOP plans to repeal the ACA, they better sure have an actual plan that will protect the American people.

Yesterday, more than 30 bomb-threats were called into American Jewish institutions. Just 10 days prior, 16 Jewish institutions were targeted. Florida community centers have been targeted both times.   I am deeply concerned by this wave of hate, and extend my support and gratitude to law-enforcement officials working to find those responsible.

When I announced my intention to boycott the inauguration earlier this week, I made it clear that the decision was not a protest of the results of the Electoral College, but rather, an objection to the President’s very un-presidential attitude and behavior. The office of the President is nothing to take lightly. I certainly do not. It is the highest office in our country and the most powerful in the world. President Trump has yet to show me that he is ready to assume the awesome powers that come with it.   The President and I will undoubtedly disagree on many issues. That is the way democracies work, and I hope that our country will have the ability to debate our differences with the serious attention they deserve. Name-calling, ridicule, and insults do not have a place on our national stage.   As I said previously, it is quite simply wrong for the President to use his position of power to continue to make racist, sexist, and bigoted statements that demean American citizens in order to score points with his political base. I will not play a part in normalizing divisive rhetoric that adds nothing to the critical conversations we face in the near future.  Today, I hope, and I pray, that the President rises to meet the responsibilities of his new position, starting immediately. But as I said previously, if the Trump administration champions illegal, unconstitutional, or other ideas that put the safety of the American people at risk, it will find no harsher critic than me.
I will be on To the Point with Michael Williams this coming Sunday, January 22, 2017, to discuss my decision to boycott the Presidential inauguration as well as issues facing the 115th Congress.

Once again, we mark the anniversary of the Supreme Court’s Roe v. Wade decision as women’s reproductive rights are under attack across the country. Roe v. Wade gives women the right to make their own choices and control their own bodies, yet Republicans across the country continue pushing an extreme agenda to overturn these protections.   The Republicans' obsession with cutting off access to women’s healthcare is deeply disturbing. President Trump has even went as far to say that women who receive abortions under any circumstance, even when the life of the mother is in danger, should be punished – a clear violation of the law. President Trump needs to educate himself on history and the law, and should work with Democrats to strengthen the protections that have made healthcare safer for countless women.  As we mark the anniversary of Roe v. Wade, I am proud to support the right to reproductive healthcare. Neither Congress or the President have the right to place restrictions on a woman’s Constitutionally-protected freedom of choice, and I continue to oppose any efforts to weaken or eliminate access to women’s healthcare providers across the country. #Roe44 #7in10forRoe

It has been seven years since the Supreme Court’s disastrous Citizens United decision dramatically altered political spending in our country.  The Citizens United ruling has opened the floodgates to corporations and special interest groups, allowing them to make unlimited contributions and political expenditures to influence elections, SuperPACs have poured hundreds of millions of dollars into campaigns across the country. In the 2016 election cycle alone, these expenditures topped $1.1 billion.    Dark money continues to make our elections more and more costly, and more and more exclusive. The American people deserve an equitable and transparent electoral system that ensures our government is accountable to the interests of voters and not the wealthy elite. I am disappointed that Republicans in Congress continue to oppose Democrats efforts to establish a more transparent process.     As we mark the 7th anniversary of Citizens United, I remain committed to enacting critical new reforms that will empower the American voter and restore accountability to our nation’s electoral process.

The House Republican leadership has chosen legislation attacking women’s reproductive rights as their very first priority following President Trump’s inauguration. The legislation being debated today by the House Rules Committee is nothing more than a continuation of the Republicans' war on women and part of the Trump-Ryan agenda that seeks to punish women for making their own healthcare decisions.  Further, the fact that President Trump chose to reinstate the Global Gag Rule in his first set of Executive Orders is very telling about his priorities. Reinstating this failed policy will actively prevent vulnerable women in developing countries from receiving life-saving healthcare, and will result in many unwanted pregnancies and deaths worldwide.  Yesterday, our nation marked the 44th anniversary of Roe v. Wade. Sadly, Republicans are stuck in the past and remain obsessed with controlling women’s reproductive rights, both here at home and around the globe.  Women are already denied abortion coverage because of how much they earn. H.R. 7 is an insulting bill that doubles down on that sentiment by making insurance coverage bans permanent, disproportionately impacting low-income families and women of color.  Instead of using the House’s time to address healthcare, job creation, or national security, Republicans have shown where their true priorities lie. Neither Congress nor the courts have the right to place restrictions on a woman’s constitutionally protected freedom of choice. I will continue to oppose these misguided efforts that seek to roll-back women’s rights in America. #Roe44 #TrumpGlobalGag

President Trump’s decision to revive the Keystone XL and Dakota Access Pipelines is a clear demonstration that he puts the oil industry above the interests of the American people. It is very disappointing that on the same day that Senate Democrats proposed a historic plan to rebuild our crumbling infrastructure and create over 15 million jobs, President Trump’s administration doubled down on his support for dirty fuels. If President Trump is serious about long-term, sustainable job creation, he should join Democrats in supporting the clean energy industries of the future rather than the dirty industries of the past.   In addition to demonstrating contempt for Native Americans and the Standing Rock Sioux Nation Tribe, this action revives the false choice of supporting either job growth or the environment. We can lead the world in renewable energy jobs, ushering in a new era of clean technology and good jobs, without putting at risk clean water and sacred tribal burial and archaeological sites.  President Trump has said repeatedly that he wants to bring people together, yet just days into his presidency he has consistently steamrolled groups opposing his policies. By putting the oil industry over the American people, President Trump has demonstrated once again that he hasn’t the first clue of how to govern for all. #NoDAPL #NoKXL

There is zero evidence of widespread voter fraud, yet this administration continues to spread vicious lies under the guise of ‘alternative facts’ in order to distract the American people from the fact that the President is not on their side. Using conjured allegations of voter fraud to make it harder for minorities, elderly, young, and poor Americans to vote is not just wrong, it is un-American.

Hundreds of terrorist attacks have been carried out in #Israel throughout the past year and a half. Even as stabbings, shootings, and car-ramming attacks occur nearly every day, the international community has failed to clearly condemn these blatant acts of terrorism.   That is why Rob Woodall and I introduced a bi-partisan resolution today which clearly illustrates the severity of the violence and urges the international community to speak up. Unless the Palestinian government and leaders around the world unequivocally condemn these acts of terror, there is little chance it will stop.

I join with others around the world in observing International Holocaust Remembrance Day and honoring the millions of lives tragically cut short during the worst genocide in human history. Between 1940 and 1945, two out of every three Jews in Europe perished, and by the end of World War II, nearly eleven million people had been murdered by the Nazis.   Today, a global resurgence in anti-Semitism has emerged, to which the United States is not immune. In recent months, acts of intimidation and violence against Jewish Americans and other minorities have increased dramatically. I have no doubt that the demagogic campaign run by President Trump – a campaign to divide our nation that has yet to cease – has fostered an atmosphere that allows those who embrace bigotry to be emboldened. Scores of anti-Semitic hate crimes have occurred in our country in recent months, including numerous bomb-threats and acts of harassment throughout my home state of Florida. I condemn these acts of hate and pledge to continue doing my part to combat intolerance.   As we observe International #HolocaustRemembranceDay, we must do more to fight back against bigotry. Blind hatred has no place in our world, and each of us has the responsibility to make our own communities safer, more tolerant places.

When the body of Alan Kurdi washed up onto the shores of Greece, the echoes of condemnation reverberated around the world. Where is that shock and outrage today?    President Trump’s #MuslimBan is government-mandated persecution. It is immoral, illegal, and a stain on America. History will judge us for this failure.

The impetus for the creation of the Affordable Care Act was to make health care more affordable for the American people. Here is yet one more example of corporate executives raising the list prices of life saving drugs to unconscionable levels in order to pad their bottom lines. Patients come before profits. Congress needs to act rein in big-pharma’s outdated system. http://bit.ly/2jFpdyw

Over the weekend, President Trump downgraded top National Security Council defense and intelligence professionals and elevated fringe political advisor Steve Bannon in their place. The decisions weighed by the National Security Council are literally life-or-death and quite serious. We should not be playing politics with our nation’s security.

President Trump’s dismissal of Acting Attorney General Sally Yates is an alarming escalation of his administration’s vilification of dissent. The Attorney General owes his or her loyalty to the law, not the White House. President Trump appears to have a fundamental misunderstanding of what it means to honor our country’s dedication to the rule of law.   When Cabinet nominees are vetted, they are asked whether they will stand up to the President if ordered to enforce illegal actions. In refusing to enforce an executive action that is both illegal and immoral, Mrs. Yates demonstrated the exact characteristics we seek out in our Attorneys General. I commend Mrs. Yates for her distinguished record of service, and her courage in taking a stand against injustice.

Black History Month is an opportunity to celebrate the rich traditions of African American culture and to recognize the countless contributions African Americans have made to our society. African Americans have done much to shape America into the nation it is today, and I take great pride in the achievements of our community.   As we reflect on these accomplishments, we must also remember that great injustices still exist. Our nation finds itself refighting many of the struggles of past generations as the hard-fought victories of the Civil Rights Movement face new threats. Voter suppression laws that disproportionally affect communities of color have been enacted in dozens of states, while other disparities in wealth, education, and employment are commonplace amongst minority communities. These issues affect all Americans, and we must all work together to address them.  This month, I draw inspiration from leaders like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Congresswoman Shirley Chisholm, Justice Thurgood Marshall, and President Barack Obama. Let us each mark #BlackHistoryMonth by rededicating ourselves to the fight for equality for all Americans. #BHM

I spoke on the House floor yesterday about President Trump’s disastrous #MuslimBan. The White House froze Congress and federal agencies out of the process, leading to mass confusion and the detainment of scores of people. Shameful. #NoBanNoWall

President Trump has, not surprisingly, squandered his opportunity to nominate a mainstream jurist respected across the aisle. In nominating Judge Neil Gorsuch, President Trump selected a fringe jurist with a history of issuing troubling decisions. In the past, he has sided with employers meddling in their female employees’ healthcare decisions, defended the rights of Wall Street over the rights of working families, and been particularly hostile towards anti-discrimination laws and criminal justice reforms. Judge Gorsuch’s record suggests that he will dismantle critical federal regulations, overturn Roe v. Wade, and would be corporations’ dream justice.  President Trump had a great opportunity to repair the damage that Senate Republicans inflicted on America when they took an empty Supreme Court seat hostage almost a year ago. After what Republicans did to President Obama and Judge Merick Garland, President Trump’s demand for a speedy confirmation for Neil Gorsuch is laughable at best.  If Judge Gorsuch is confirmed, there is no doubt that fringe Republicans will be celebrating. Women, workers, consumers, and mainstream Americans will have far less to celebrate. #SCOTUS

Seventeen years ago, National Black HIV/AIDS Awareness Day was first observed in order to raise awareness about the impact of the HIV/AIDS epidemic on African Americans. Today, National Black HIV/AIDS Awareness Day continues to serve as a valuable mobilization effort encouraging African Americans to be aware, be informed, and to get treated.    Unfortunately, what was true last year and in years prior remains true today: HIV/AIDS affects African Americans more than any other racial or ethnic group in the United States.  While African Americans represent only 12 percent of the population, they account for almost 45 percent of new HIV diagnoses each year.  Of those new diagnoses, an estimated 57 percent are gay or bisexual men, or men who have sex with men (MSM). And of that group, 39 percent are young men aged 13 to 24. Despite this harsh reality, I am committed to ending this pandemic once and for all.   Thanks to medical advances, people are living longer and healthier lives, but there is still much to be done in order to meet our goal of zero new infections and zero new deaths. While various barriers exist to African Americans infected with HIV/AIDS, such as stigmas, equal access to healthcare and higher rates of poverty, we have the power to make an HIV/AIDS-free society.   On this National Black HIV/AIDS Awareness Day, I pledge to continue working with my colleagues in Congress, healthcare providers, and community leaders to support HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment efforts. #NBHAAD2017

The 9th Circuit’s ruling was a major victory for America. The President's illegal refugee ban goes against our values & must be completely withdrawn.
Hundreds of my constituents have been denied tours of The White House or left in limbo. What’s taking so long?
I'm looking forward to hosting the first Florida Delegation Meeting of the 115th Congress with Congressman Vern Buchanan on water issues facing coastal communities.

Michael Flynn’s resignation just three weeks into President Trump’s Administration underscores the severity of the threat of Russian influence on the President. The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) must move expeditiously to investigate Flynn to determine the extent of his illegal communications with the Russian government, to what degree President Trump was involved, and what actions the White House took after being informed of these communications nearly one month ago.  It is noticeable that the House Oversight Committee has remained silent through a number of Trump Administration blunders. House Republican leadership must stop stalling and establish an independent commission to fully investigate Russian influence in the American election and President Trump’s Administration. At this point, anything otherwise should be seen as complicit. #FlynnResignation FBI – Federal Bureau of Investigation

As of today, H.Res.30 has 93 co-sponsors. As we continue to recruit supporters for this resolution, I wanted to again thank everyone who is working tirelessly to help get it passed! Stay tuned for more big news, and let’s keep up the pressure! #HRes30 #Yulin #EndDogMeatTrade #StopYulinForever

The Republican Congress is pushing through a resolution today supporting offensive, expensive, and unconstitutional blanket drug testing of Americans applying for unemployment compensation. Even though there is no evidence to support this claim, Republicans are focusing on this non-issue instead of legislation investing in jobs and infrastructure, reforming our immigration system, or improving health care. In a U.S. News Op-Ed, Christine Owens, Executive Director of the National Employment Project, highlights that SAMHSA estimates the costs of drug tests at $25-$75 per test – costs that are passed directly onto states.   What we have here is yet another example of legislation based on “alternative facts” and Trumpian logic.

As the 115th Congress gets underway, I continue to push for the passage of H.Res.30, my resolution condemning the annual dog meat festival in #Yulin, China and calling on the Chinese Government to end the dog-meat trade. The Yulin festival celebrates animal cruelty. Practices like this have no place in the 21st century, and I am pleased to lead this effort to advocate for animal welfare standards across the globe. #EndDogMeatTrade #StopYulinForever

For the fourth time in five weeks a wave of bomb threats has threatened Jewish Community Centers across the country. These threats of violence are deeply alarming, particularly against the backdrop of growing rates of anti-Semitic attacks and vandalism throughout the United States.    This wave of hate requires urgent action, and I urge Attorney General Sessions and FBI Director Comey to take the appropriate steps to combat this growing trend. I again extend my gratitude to law-enforcement officials and all those working to find those responsible.

In rescinding guidance issued by President Obama’s Administration, President Trump has abandoned transgender students across the country. I am deeply disappointed by the Administration’s retraction of these important protections that benefit nearly 150,000 transgender students.      This is not a states’ rights issue as the White House has falsely claimed. Title IX prohibits all public schools from discriminating against students based on sex. All students, regardless of sex or gender, are deserving of equal protections under the law, period. The White House should not be picking and choosing which students are deserving of federal protections.   Passing the buck under the false pretense of 'states’ rights' is not acceptable leadership. President Trump continues to abdicate his responsibilities as President. In recent years, great progress has been made in fully recognizing the equal rights due to the LGBTQ community, and I will continue to push for more progress, not less.

Throughout the past week I held important meetings on #HumanRights and national security in Europe and the Middle East. As President Emeritus of the OSCE Parliamentary Assembly (Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe), I was pleased to attend the 17th Annual Winter Meeting in Vienna, Austria, and hold multiple bi-lateral and multi-lateral meetings in Italy, Jordan, and Israel.

This Wednesday I will be hosting a meeting of the Congressional #Everglades Caucus with Congressman Mario Diaz-Balart. I’m looking forward to hearing directly from county representatives on their needs for the upcoming year to improve South #Florida’s water management.

House Republicans continued their assault on well thought-out policy today, taking aim at OSHA standards that protect the health and safety of American workers.   I can’t help but notice that 40 days into President Trump’s administration, he has not put forth one single jobs measure. I think it’s fitting that we take a moment to reflect on the priorities that House Republicans have focused on instead.

Apparently Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos does not understand the difference between school choice and legalized racism under Jim Crow. Before setting the direction for our nation’s schools, she should educate herself on why historically black colleges and universities were founded in the first place, and the enduring disenfranchisement that still exists today as a result of segregation.

When the President took office, I made it clear that I would work with his administration wherever possible. Even though we disagree on many issues, the role of the President is to facilitate national debates with the serious attention they deserve. To this end, I have been consistently disappointed by the first weeks of the President’s Administration.  The United States is at its best when we draw strength from each other. President Trump has taken the opposite tack, surrounding himself with sycophants, lambasting the independent media, and censuring anyone who thinks differently. Ridiculing the minority is un-presidential, and the only thing tonight’s speech accomplished was to illustrate just how little the President understands about America.   The President has been in office for just 40 days, yet he has already established himself as one of the most reckless in American history. President Trump continues to champion divisive policies that would decimate safety-net programs, while propping up his own wasteful pet projects like the border wall with Mexico. These proposals would be laughable if they weren’t so frighteningly ill-conceived.  At this point during the Obama Administration, the President had already proposed and signed into law a plan that would create millions of jobs and jumpstart the American economy. President Obama, four weeks into his Administration, had already signed legislation to support fair pay for women and expand health insurance for children. When he came before Congress for his first joint session, he presented a vision of an America for all.   Four weeks into his administration, President Trump has presented no jobs bill, no plan for healthcare, and has offered nothing to improve the lives of everyday Americans. Instead, he has elevated a white supremacist to the National Security Council and been caught pressuring the FBI to undermine an investigation of the Administration’s ties to Russian intelligence. This is, quite simply, unacceptable.   Throughout the past week, concerned Americans attended town halls across the country. And for those who were actually able to meet with their Republican Representative in Congress, the conversations focused on protecting healthcare, creating jobs, and protecting the environment. They did not ask for fewer workplace protections, nor did they ask Congress to make it easier for people with severe mental illnesses to purchase guns. They did not ask Congress to undermine retirement security or ease disclosure requirements for oil companies making payments to foreign governments. Yet, these are the things that President Trump and the Republican Party have championed.  These are policies of a cynical and callous government, and Democrats will not sit idly by while President #Trump and his Republican allies continue their efforts to unravel this great nation. #JointAddress

Hundreds of thousands of innocent Syrians have been killed and millions more displaced over the last few years. This week’s chemical weapon attack perpetrated by the Assad regime is a horrific continuation of this violence and a crime against humanity.   It is a sad state of affairs for this nation that Congress has continued to sit idly by while the Executive Branch further engages our military in conflicts overseas without Congressional authorization. This dereliction is no fault of President Donald John Trump’s, but it does our entire nation a disservice. For too long, Congress has not had the opportunity to weigh in on decisions to commit American troops to conflicts abroad. This cannot continue. I, like many others, am reflecting today as our nation marks the 10th anniversary of the mass shooting on the campus of Virginia Tech. At the time, it was the deadliest mass shooting in our nation’s history. Thirty-two people were murdered that day, both students and instructors. Many died while protecting their classmates and colleagues, barricading doors or even attempting to stop the gunman. Heroes like Liviu Librescu, a survivor of the Holocaust, sacrificed their lives so that students and instructors alike could live. The stories from this tragedy are haunting.  On this solemn day, as we mourn those who were lost, we must also recognize that not enough has changed in the wake of this tragedy and dozens of others. A national cry for improved gun control has fallen on too many deaf ears. We know that something needs to change to prevent future tragedies, yet this change has not come. Today is a day of remembrance, but it is not enough to simply remember. We must honor the past by looking to the future and continuing to fight for commonsense progress that will curtail gun violence.  Nearly 35,000 Americans die every year from guns. We cannot simply accept this as part of America.

I am delighted to congratulate the State of Israel on its 69th Independence Day. I join with the Israeli people in celebrating Israel’s storied history and the special relationship between our two countries.  Israel’s story is no less remarkable today as it was when it was founded 69 years ago. Rising from the ashes of one of the greatest human catastrophes the world has ever witnessed, the people of Israel have built a modern, thriving nation. From the high-tech hub of Tel Aviv to the cultural center of Jerusalem, the State of Israel stands out as an example of democracy in a region often marred by violence and oppression. No other country has lived with such constant challenges to its right to exist, yet despite these challenges, Israel has flourished.   Too often, Israel is unfairly targeted on the world stage. As we see a resurgence of anti-Semitism and anti-Zionism, including efforts to boycott, divest, or otherwise isolate Israel, it is more important than ever that we continue to stand with our Israeli allies.   Today, the United States and Israel work together in a number of areas, including energy, medical research, high-tech and innovation, academia, and more. Through partnerships such as the Binational Industrial Research and Development (BIRD) Foundation and BIRD Energy, our countries work hand in hand to advance  research and development cooperation in the private sector for the benefit of all. As Co-Chair of the Democratic Israel Working Group, I will continue working with my fellow Members of Congress to build upon the special relationship between our two countries.  I am pleased to mark this Yom Ha’atzmaut, and extend to the people of Israel my best wishes on the 69th anniversary of Israel's Independence Day.

As we mark Memorial Day, let us join together to give thanks to the servicemen and servicewomen that have sacrificed for our country. As we honor their courage, we must reflect on the ideals for which they served and rededicate ourselves to upholding these quintessential American values.   In recognizing those who have bravely served our country, we must acknowledge the many challenges facing veterans today. Although we have successfully cut veteran homelessness by half since 2010, Veteran healthcare services are frequently overshadowed by long wait times and insufficient treatment. For others, education and workforce benefits are inadequate to support the transition back to civilian life. It is estimated that 20 veterans die by suicide each day, a figure that throws the failures of our veterans’ healthcare system into sharp focus. Rectifying these issues must take priority in the coming months of the 115th Congress.  With almost 1.7 million veterans in Florida and 34,000 in my Congressional district, I am proud to work closely with the Department of Veterans’ Affairs (VA) hospitals in West Palm Beach and Miami, as well as local clinics and medical facilities to ensure the well-being of the Florida veterans community. President Trump’s intention to pull the United States out of the Paris Climate Agreement is an irresponsible renouncement of American leadership. The results of abandoning this international framework will be tragic, destructive, and costly, and will undermine the legitimacy of our country on the global stage.   The United States cannot allow its foreign policy to be dictated by irrational nationalistic whims. The 195 signatory Paris Agreement was reached after painstaking negotiations.  In signing, our country honored its commitment to leave future generations with a better world. Climate change is real, and we know what causes it. The Paris Agreement commits governments to working together to cap pollution levels and combat carbon emissions, which will reduce extreme climate events like drought, famine, and rising sea levels.   Ignoring our international responsibilities jeopardizes the health and future of our country.  President Trump needs to recognize that he is the President for all Americans, not just the privileged few.   This destructive and short-sighted decision will have serious consequences, and the President should be held accountable for his irresponsible actions.

The start of June marks the beginning of LBGT Pride Month and the 48th anniversary of the Stonewall Riots. I would like to wish all of my friends in the LGBT community a ‘Happy Pride.’ This month, we celebrate the individuals who continue to fight for freedom, fairness, and equal opportunity for all.  I am proud to be an original cosponsor of H.R.2282, the Equality Act, legislation recently introduced in Congress that would amend the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to include sex, sexual orientation, and gender identity among the prohibited categories of discrimination.   Although we continue to make momentous strides toward equality, the Trump Administration and many of my Republican colleagues have turned a blind eye towards the needs of the LGBT community in the United States and around the world. While we still face many challenges, I will always be an advocate for equality and justice in the LGBT community. I encourage my colleagues in Congress and all Americans to join me in doing so. This month, I am proud to recognize and celebrate LGBT Pride Month.

My thoughts and prayers are with the people of London tonight as the United Kingdom copes with another horrific act of terrorism. The United States will continue to stand with our allies overseas as we work together to combat extremism of any form. I offer my deepest condolences to the families that lost loved ones this evening.

Republican Members of Congress have a bad habit of ignoring the devastation brought by gun violence. All too frequently, calls for action go on unanswered - if not entirely ignored - by my Republican colleagues, even as Americans are killed by firearms on a daily basis.    It has now been one year since the shooting at the Pulse Nightclub. Despite the public outcry, protests, and even a Congressional sit-in, the largest mass shooting in the history of our nation could not shake Republicans to break with the extreme voices in their party. No new laws have been enacted and nothing has changed. This to me is absolutely shameful!   On this solemn anniversary, I call on my colleagues in Congress, with particular regard to those who have stood in the way of common sense gun reform in the past, to join me and other Democrats in advocating for smart gun control policies that will save American lives. I honor the memories of those who were killed, and rededicate myself to advocating for the survivors of this horrific mass shooting.

My thoughts and prayers are with Congressman Steve Scalise, my GOP colleagues, their staffs, and the U.S. Capitol Police officers wounded in this morning’s horrific shooting. As the details come to light, I thank the first responders who reacted so quickly and professionally to protect my colleagues and their staffs.

Since DACA was launched five years ago, nearly 800,000 young people have received temporary relief from deportation. The program has afforded youth the opportunity to work, go to school, and be active and contributing members of our society.   President Donald John Trump’s administration has undermined DACA, targeting recipients with deportation or stripping the program's protections for minor infractions. We should be building on the success of this program, not undermining our own solution. It makes no sense to educate young people and then turn around and deport them, oftentimes to countries they have never known or have little to no connection with. And yet, the Administration and the GOP controlled Congress have pushed draconian immigration policies that target immigrants and severely impact families and communities.  In marking the success of this program, we celebrate the young migrants who have been given another chance to pursue the American Dream. I am a proud co-sponsor of H.R. 1487, the Dreamer Protection Act, which protects recipients of DACA from being targeted due to changes by the President, and continue to advocate for smart immigration policy and comprehensive reform. I vow to continue to advocate for these youth, and am proud to mark the success of DACA and its recipients.

Two years after President Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation black Americans remained enslaved in parts of the country. It was not until Major General Gordon Granger landed his regiment in Galveston, Texas, 152 years ago today, that all Americans were finally freed from bondage.   The observation of #Juneteenth is bittersweet. While holidays like this one remind us of how lucky we are to be alive today, they also remind us that no matter how far we’ve come, the disparities that exist for people of color are still significant. Even after the abolition of slavery, it took another century and a civil rights movement unrivaled in human history to bring freedom to all Americans. And yet, discrimination and inequalities continue today.   I join with so many across the country in drawing from the past generations of Americans who inspired us to dream. We celebrate our freedom and our achievements, and rededicate ourselves to the continued struggle for equal rights and justice for all.
NA

We observe #WorldRefugeeDay to draw attention to the plight of the more than 65 million people around the globe who have been forced to flee their homes and countries. More than any time in recorded history, war, persecution, religious intolerance, and natural disasters have forced millions of people to abandon everything in order to survive. On this day, we must reflect on the importance of promoting democracy and freedom around the world so that those affected by humanitarian disasters may one day return to their homes.   I have been to dozens of refugee camps throughout my time in Congress, and have seen firsthand the desperation and the resolve held by refugees in search of safety. I commend the work that the United Nations High Commission on Refugees (UNHCR) has done to provide basic resources for refugee populations, and join in urging the international community, the United States included, to do more to accommodate refugees and alleviate suffering, violence and persecution.

I continue to support a two-state solution, negotiated between the State of Israel and the Palestinian Authority, and resulting in two states for two peoples, living side-by-side in peace, security, and mutual recognition. In recent years, Israel and some of her Arab neighbors have worked to address common challenges and improve bilateral relations. This engagement is commendable, and it presents a new opportunity for improving the outlook of the Middle East.   Although there are rarely, if ever, easy solutions to challenges as complex as bringing lasting peace to the Middle East, Congress should encourage and support those states willing to engage in that endeavor.  Thank you Rep. Eliot Engel and Rep. David Schweikert for introducing this bipartisan resolution with me.

It is completely outrageous that the Yulin authorities and Chinese government failed to take any meaningful action to bring an end to this year’s #Yulin Dog Meat Festival. This festival and others like it that celebrate the torture of dogs and cats is an abhorrent display of animal cruelty.  No one can see these images and walk away unaffected.  I proudly stand with the millions of people across the globe and in China, who wish to see this horrific festival come to an end once and for all. I once again want to thank the countless activists who continue their tireless fight every single day in order to save and protect the voiceless.

Today, I introduced a bipartisan resolution with Congressman Vern Buchanan urging an end to the global dog and cat meat trade.  I believe that Congress must take immediate action by sending a strong message to all nations, that it will not tolerate the brutal and inhumane torture and consumption of dog and cat meat.  The dog and cat meat trade must be ended around the world once and for all!  I urge Speaker Paul Ryan and Rep. Kevin McCarthy to bring this bipartisan measure to the floor without delay.
Next week, Congressman Vern Buchanan and I will host a Florida delegation meeting on human trafficking in our state.

The Senate TrumpCare bill is indefensible! For Majority Leader McConnell to champion legislation that will purposefully kick 22 million people off of their healthcare is an absurd display of partisanship, which should outrage every American across this nation.    Half a trillion dollars in tax cuts for millionaires and big corporations is not healthcare policy, just as stealing nearly a trillion dollars from Medicaid is not healthcare reform. Republicans are having so many problems with their so-called bill, because they have frozen Democrats out of the process, and put their party ahead of our country.   The Affordable Care Act is not perfect and needs to be improved.  I don’t think anyone denies that.  However, it makes no sense to throw out all of the progress we have made on a partisan whim, rather than address the real challenges that we can work on together in a bipartisan basis.   Rather than keeping up this charade on the taxpayers’ dime, Majority Leader McConnell should work with both Democrats and Republicans to draft a bill that works for all Americans.

Congressman Vern Buchanan and I hosted a Florida Delegation meeting today on human trafficking in our state. I want thank our expert panelists who travelled to Washington to share their perspectives on how to better to address this form of modern-day slavery.

Today, I join with all Americans in celebrating our nation’s Independence Day. As we commemorate the 241st anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, we must recognize that our country’s achievements have not come without great cost. Countless Americans have selflessly given their lives in defense of our nation, so that we may live in a freer world.    While we have achieved great things in our nation’s short but storied existence, challenges facing us seem weightier than any time in recent memory. For too many people across the country, inadequacies in healthcare and education have eroded many peoples’ hope for the future. The American Dream is built upon hope, and until these inequities are corrected nationwide, the principles enshrined in our founding document – liberty, justice, and equality – will never be truly realized.   As we gather with our loved ones, let us remember the principles that bind us together as one people. I wish my constituents and all Americans a safe and happy Independence Day!

Once again UNESCO has adopted an anti-Semitic and revisionist resolution seeking to write Jewish religion and culture out of world history. This biased resolution, notably adopted by secret ballot, is delusional. It does nothing to positively improve the lives of the Palestinian people. Jewish ties to Hebron are irrefutable, and no UN resolution, however backwards or prejudiced, will ever change that. There is no need for divisiveness in the home of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob that are revered by Jews, Christians, and Muslims.

I was honored to once again represent the United States and Congress at this year’s Annual Meeting of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe’s Parliamentary Assembly. Our delegation was the largest U.S. delegation to have ever visited Minsk.   The OSCE PA plays a critical role in multilateral dialogue, which promotes security, human rights and economic development. Throughout the past week, I participated in a number of high-level meetings with senior representatives of OSCE states to enhance cooperation between our countries.

UNESCO’s inscription of Hebron as a Palestinian World Heritage Site is the height of absurdity. It seems as if every time I turn around the United Nations (UN) or one of its agencies is attempting to rewrite Jewish history out of world history. The biased resolution passed last week by the World Heritage Committee is a perfect example of this foolish trend.  The UN does itself a great disservice when it allows these revisionist measures to move forward. In the past year, it has pushed resolutions that have omitted Jewish identity from the Temple Mount, which is the most holy place in Judaism and named for the location of the Jewish Temple that stood more than two thousand years ago, and also chastised Israel for planting ‘fake Jewish graves’ in the vicinity. This is ridiculous and bordering on anti-Semitism.   Even as wars and humanitarian disasters rage across the globe, the UN remains relentless in its anti-Israel agenda. I therefore felt it necessary to introduce this resolution today disapproving of UNESCO’s inscription of Hebron and its Cave of the Patriarchs – the second holiest place in the Jewish faith – as a Palestinian World Heritage Site in Danger.

I am so truly honored to receive the Lifetime Achievement Award from National Security Executives and Professionals Association. Throughout my tenure in Congress, including as the former Vice Chairman of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, and as the current Ranking Democratic Member of the U.S. Helsinki Commission, I have long championed security policies to keep our country safe and promote international stability.   NSEPA does critically important work in promoting career enhancement opportunity for African Americans, women, and other ethnically diverse national security and intelligence professionals. A diverse workforce is an American workforce, and empowering minority security professionals builds a stronger foundation for keeping our country competitive and secure. I thank NSEPA for being bestowed with this prestigious award, and remain committed to doing all that I can in Congress to advocate for addressing the underrepresentation of ethnically diverse groups of employees across the federal workforce.

The reason that TrumpCare keeps falling apart is because it is cruel. It is simply not realistic to gut programs like Medicaid or end the essential health benefits that tens of millions of people rely upon. TrumpCare puts partisan grandstanding ahead of realistic reforms.   Even after this failure, Congressional Republicans briefly went back to the ‘repeal-only’ approach that would strip healthcare coverage from 32 million people. Given that they have spent the last seven years trashing the Affordable Care Act, it is baffling to me that those pushing repeal haven’t learned a thing. Just hours after announcing this new strategy, the ‘repeal-only’ approach has already fallen apart.    There is no question that improvements to healthcare need to be made. Reforms can be enacted in a matter of weeks, if not days. But when bipartisanship is used as a threat, as Senate Majority Leader McConnell has done in the past, it underscores how the Republican Party isn’t interested in working across the aisle even as people are asking for help.   Democrats won’t let the Republican Party destroy healthcare, but we will work together to improve the system. Speaker Ryan and Majority Leader McConnell should work with both Democrats and Republicans to draft a bill that works for all Americans.

President Trump’s announcement that he will ban transgender troops from serving openly in our military is shortsighted and cruel. It will leave our country more vulnerable to the threats we face in the months and years to come.   As many as 11,000 transgender service members currently serve honorably in our armed forces. Arbitrarily discharging them solely because of their gender identity is hateful and unpatriotic.   President Harry Truman abolished the Armed Forces’ policy of racial segregation 69 years ago today. President Truman knew then what our current President is incapable of understanding today: the strength of our military is not found in labels like race, religion, creed, sex, or gender identity, but rather in the bravery and honor exhibited by those that choose to serve our nation.  Donald J. Trump: You don’t know the first things about service. Shame on you!

My thoughts and prayers are with the families of those killed and with the many who were injured following the senseless and hate-filled violence by white supremacists in Charlottesville, Virginia.    The images of Nazi and Confederate battle flags being waved by white supremacists yesterday are chilling. These “protestors” marched in order to terrorize innocent Americans. They are radical extremists and racists, and their cowardly acts of violence must not be tolerated.    President Trump’s refusal to condemn yesterday’s alt-right rally and subsequent violence is both a moral failure and a failure of leadership. The fact that he has once again met white supremacist violence with ambivalence is shameful.   The resurgence of emboldened public racism in our country lies at the President’s feet. History will judge him and condemn him for it, along with the members of his own party who refuse to speak out.

Today’s comments by President Trump were completely appalling. What took place in in Charlottesville was an act of domestic terrorism, not a two-sided affair.    The President has lost all moral authority to lead this nation. By continuing to stand with white supremacists promoting the abhorrent, anti-democratic ideologies of inequality, injustice, and fascism, President Trump is fueling the fires of hate. This is completely outrageous, and every single elected representative to Congress, regardless of party, must hold him to account.

The collision of the USS John S. McCain near the Straight of Malacca is a reminder of the inherent dangers faced by our servicemen and women. As search and rescue crews continue to work, I offer my prayers for those injured or still missing from this tragic accident.

President Trump declared that Americans are ‘weary of war without victory.’ Americans are weary of war, period. For more than 17 years, our country has waged a seemingly never-ending war in Afghanistan, at a cost of thousands of lives and hundreds of billions of dollars.    The American people deserve to know what President Trump is asking of their sons and daughters. In that regards, the President’s address was unacceptably vague. By refusing to detail the number of troops he will deploy or the missions they will be tasked with, the President has positioned himself to drag out our nation’s longest military conflict indefinitely, in sharp contrast to his statements on the campaign trail.    Further, in openly declaring the end of American-led democracy building, President Trump has doubled down on his administration’s abdication of leadership across the globe. As the Ranking Democratic Member of the U.S. Helsinki Commission, I have long championed democracy and human rights reforms in nations making the difficult transition towards free and open societies. In announcing this decision, President Trump has given authoritarian despots tacit approval to continue abusing and violating the rights of their citizens with impunity.    This address underscores the importance of passing a new AUMF dictating a clear and coherent strategy for American military engagements in Afghanistan. Congress has the constitutional authority to lead this conversation, yet for too long has ceded this immense responsibility. Speaker Ryan must making passage of a new AUMF the first priority when the House of Representatives returns to session.
I’ll be a guest on To the Point this weekend to discuss the issues facing Congress. Tune into WPTV-5 this Sunday at 10:00 AM.

The decision announced today was based upon the same bigoted arguments that were used to justify keeping our military segregated many decades ago. Arbitrarily discharging transgender troops solely because of their gender identity is an act of hate and harmful to our nation's security. I've come to expect nothing less from this President, who refused to condemn neo-Nazis and fascists. It is clear that he hasn't learned a thing since taking office. He should be ashamed of himself.

As the people of Texas continue to grapple with the devastation caused by Hurricane Harvey, I offer my full support to the thousands of families coping with this tragedy. I join with so many around the country in keeping the people of Texas in my thoughts and prayers.    The threats from this storm have not yet passed, and many of our fellow citizens still face immediate danger and the prospect of long-term displacement from their homes and communities. I thank the first responders and the ordinary citizens working day and night to save lives, as well as those working to keep emergency shelters available to those in need.    When disasters strike, Americans stand together. The road to recovery from this storm will be long, and Congress must act swiftly to give local officials the resources they need to safeguard their communities and begin the painful process of rebuilding. This is a storm of historic proportions, and our response must be equally prodigious. When Congress reconvenes, we must prioritize passing a bipartisan emergency relief package that provides the necessary funding to recover from this horrific storm.

On #LaborDay, let us pay tribute to the hardworking men and women who are the backbone of our great nation.  Please take a minute to read my op-ed published in the South Florida Sun Sentinel on the need to improve pay and benefits for American workers. #Fightfor15   I hope that you have a safe and restful Labor Day.

President Trump’s decision to terminate the #DACA program is both illogical and immoral. Just one day after our nation marked Labor Day, the President’s decision will cost our country tens of thousands of jobs and billions of dollars in revenue. More importantly, this decision tells the more than 800,000 DACA recipients that they are neither valued nor wanted, while in truth, they are invaluable.     DACA recipients are here in search of the American dream: to better their education and to make a better life for themselves and their families. Casting them aside as lawbreakers or criminals is reprehensible.    In February, President Trump pledged to address DREAMERs and immigration reform ‘with heart.’ He promised that he would ‘take care of everybody.’ Just last week, Vice President Pence reiterated that the President would act with ‘big heart’ to ensure that undocumented immigrants benefiting from DACA would be treated fairly. Regrettably, we have been reminded once again just how heartless this President is.   President Trump’s about-face means that Congress must get to work at once to protect DREAMERs. My Republican colleagues now have a choice: stand with their President, or stand with their country. It is far past time for Congress to come together and fix our broken immigration system by providing a path to citizenship that is fair to all people – those who already call America home and those who yearn to enjoy our country’s dedication to liberty and freedom for all.

It is with great sadness that I learned of the passing of Diane Glasser this morning. As an activist, former City Commissioner, and Vice Mayor of the City of Tamarac, Diane served our community for more than 40 years. She was a powerhouse of Broward County politics, but more than that, she was a dear friend. Her contributions will no doubt be remembered for years to come.   Before moving to Tamarac in 1973, Diane grew up in Mill Basin in Brooklyn, New York. She was appointed First Vice Chairwoman of the Florida Democratic Party in 2004. Four years later, she was elected to the Tamarac City Commission, where served until her retirement in 2016. Diane served on various boards in Broward County, including the Broward School Board, the Senior Advisory Task Force, and the Broward Human Rights Board, always striving to make our community a better place.   Diane was an Elected Florida Delegate in the last six Democratic National Conventions, and cast her vote in the Electoral College for the State of Florida in 1996 for Former President Bill Clinton and in 2000 for Former Vice President Al Gore.   Diane passed away on October 10, 2017 at the age of 89. She is survived by her son Craig Glasser of Sunrise, Florida. I offer my thoughts and prayers to Craig, her family, and all who called her a friend during this time of great sadness.

This Veterans Day, I am honored to recognize the brave men and women who have served and defended our country in the U.S. Armed Forces. Our veterans exemplify the very best of our nation, oftentimes serving in dangerous conflicts around the globe in defense of American security. The fact that our Armed Forces are comprised entirely of volunteers underscores the importance of recognizing the sacrifices that come with this service and sets the example for other countries around the world.   We have an obligation to care for service members both when they’re abroad and when they come home. Rates of veteran suicide remain disproportionately high, and many of the three million Americans who have served in Afghanistan and Iraq have Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI), Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) or depression. Congress must prioritize addressing these issues, just as it must ensure that veterans or their eligible family members have access to the educational benefits they are entitled to. We must work collaboratively to guarantee that our veterans maintain access to affordable housing and education, employment opportunities, healthcare and mental health services.    As we celebrate Veterans Day, let us honor those men and women who have defended our country. If you see a veteran today, take a moment to thank them for their service to our nation.

The AIDS epidemic is a public health crisis that affects every community. On World AIDS Day, we honor the memories of the victims of this terrible disease, and recommit ourselves to eradicating HIV/AIDS once and for all.   Despite the tragic toll of HIV/AIDS, we continue to make progress in achieving an AIDS-free generation. With continued investment and research, we will halt this pandemic in its tracks.   In the United States, we must do more to increase access to voluntary screening for HIV/AIDS and reach people with intellectual disabilities and with mobility impairment. We need to continue supporting U.S. initiatives like the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR), the Global Fund for AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, and the Ryan White AIDS Program – programs that have saved millions of lives around the world and here at home.   On World AIDS Day, and every day, I am committed to these goals, to saving lives, and to protecting these critical public health programs.

I believe that Jerusalem is and should remain the undivided capital of Israel. To deny the Jewish connection to Jerusalem would be to deny world history. That being said, the manner in which the Trump Administration has announced its recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel is of great concern.   In the context of peace negotiations between the Israelis and the Palestinians, the sensitivity of the status of Jerusalem cannot be overstated. The ramifications of this decision could be profound, and I fear that the President made his decision based on political expediency rather than sound foreign policy.   The United States has long held that the final status of Jerusalem should be determined as part of an agreement negotiated between the State of Israel and the Palestinian leadership. The President’s announcement undercuts this position, as well as the role of the United States as an honest mediator of the conflict.   This announcement puts the security of American embassies and consulates throughout the Arab world at risk. The United States should continue to support a two-state solution that provides for peace, security, and mutual recognition for both the Israeli and Palestinian people.   Earlier this year, I introduced H.Res.393, a resolution supporting a concurrent track approach to the Israeli-Palestinian Peace Process and commending those Arab states that have courageously improved their relations with Israel. I believe this is the best approach to move this process forward, while recognizing the rights of both the Israeli and Palestinian people.  In light of the President’s decision, I call on his Administration and the international community to re-engage in a serious diplomatic effort with the Government of #Israel and the Palestinian leadership to advance the peace process, including a negotiated agreement on the final status of Jerusalem.
